Aerobic oxidative desulfurization (AODS) has attracted significant attention due to the utilization of environmentally friendly and safe O2 as an oxidizing agent. However, it is still a great challenge to design metal-free catalysts that activate O2 effectively at low temperature. In this study, a triazine-based covalent organic polymer (MC-TCOP) was prepared through thermal condensation reaction, and the basic characteristics of the catalyst were analyzed by different characterization methods. The MC-TCOP was applied into the AODS reaction, and the catalytic performance reached to 99.6% under mild reaction conditions (T = 50 ℃, t = 150 min, gas flow = 90 mL/min, catalyst dosage = 0.04 g). Theoretical calculation showed O2 and dibenzothiophene (DBT) were co-adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst, and the reaction mechanism indicated the O2 was activated into •O2 − (by the charge difference between the nitrogen and carbon atoms), then the DBT was oxidized to corresponding sulphone. Moreover, reusability experiment confirmed the catalyst performance was still higher than 95% after 9 times of reusing. The MC-TCOP can be used as a metal-free and eco-friendly catalyst in AODS reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Aerobic oxidative desulfurization Covalent organic polymer Mild reaction condition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the implementation of tougher global regulations on fossil fuel emissions, desulfurization technologies have experienced rapid development in recent years [1,2]. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is effective in removing most inorganic sulfur compounds, such as H2S, but exhibits limited efficiency in the removal of thiophene and its derivatives [3]. In addition, HDS requires strict operating conditions of high temperature and operating pressure [4,5], therefore, the non-hydrodesulfurization technologies have been diffusely investigated. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) is considered as an efficient desulfurization technology for its mild process conditions and the high conversion rate of organic sulfur compounds [6,7]. NO2, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%), organic peracid and ferrate are used as oxidants in ODS process [8,9]. Among these oxidants, H2O2 is more commonly used for its strong oxidation ability to DBT and eco-friendly properties [10–13]. However, 30% aqueous solution of H2O2 will lead to a biphasic system, increasing the mass transfer resistance of aqueous and oily phases in the ODS reaction, not just that, the strong oxidation of H2O2 has risks of fire and explosion problems during storage or transportation [8,10,14]. Safer, greener, and more effective oxidants needed to be investigated. In recent years, O2 is regarded as more environment-friendly and cost-effective oxidant than H2O2 in ODS process, and aerobic oxidative desulfurization (AODS) is gradually being investigated [15–17]. However, O2 is quite difficult to be activated for its highly stable triplet ground state [18], therefore, different kinds of catalysts capable of activating O2 have been extensively studied [19,20]. Carbon-nitrogen (CN) materials are extensively studied in AODS reactions due to the C-N's “hot electrons” that cleave adsorbed O2 into reactive radicals [21,22]. Ahmed et al. has reported that they synthesized an aromatic porous polymer CN material (CAPP-DETA), the catalyst exhibited high performance of removing 100% of DBT under the optimal reaction conditions (T = 120 ℃, t = 4 h), the N sites of the DETA are the main active site for oxidating DBT (the interaction of N atom and O2 molecule) [23]. Wei et al. also reported a kind of CN material (BCN-1) of AODS reaction, and the catalyst removed 98.4% of DBT in 240 min, they concluded the high performance was attributed to the zig-N edges activated dioxygen through the electron delocalization effect [24]. However, these activation of O2 generally required high temperature, which increased energy consumption of ODS process. It is reported an emerging polymeric CN material with pretty high nitrogen content (62% in weight) is capable of promoting a variety of catalytic processes [20], the material consists of triazine units, that all C and N atoms are in stable conjugating sp2 systems, and the presence of abundant inherently electronegative N atoms make the material endow with rich surface properties (electron-rich and basic surface functionalities), which has great potential to activate O2 [20]. Triazine-based covalent organic polymers (TCOPs), a new type of N-rich organic polymer materials, attracts extensive attention for its adjustable porous structures, large surface areas, and high catalytic stability in both organic and aqueous phases. This kind of material is formed by the nonreversible chemical condensation reactions, exists strong covalent bonds (C-C, C-N, and B-N) and mesoporous structures, making it widely studied in catalysis field in recent years [25–29]. Xu et al. [30] synthesized a multifunctional hollow TCOP catalyst (H-C-CTPs) with high N content, it showed superb capacity in iodine capture (4.60 g⋅g−1 vapor or 293 mg⋅g−1 solution). The iodine-adsorbed H-C-CTPs was also successfully used in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with a pretty high stability. Synergistic effect between special hollow structure and N in HC-CTP makes it blaze a trail for designing and applying of TCOP materials. Lan et al. [31] prepared two π-conjugated TCOP catalysts (A-CTP-DPA and V-CTP-DPE) that bridged by acetylene and vinylene, and the catalysts exhibited excellent performance in the sulfides photocatalytic oxidation and amines coupling oxidation reactions. Abundant photoelectron sites in catalysts, fast photoelectron transport effect in the reaction process are the major reasons of the high activity for A-CTP-DPA and V-CTP-DPE. Based on the excellent catalytic performance of TCOP catalysts and the potential of N-containing materials in activating O2, synthesizing of TCOP materials that can activate O2 and further remove DBT under mild conditions is worth to investigate for us. In this work, the catalyst MC-TCOP that formed from melamine (MA) and cyanuric chloride (CNC) was synthesized, so was the compared catalyst TT-COP (no triazine structure), formed from 1,3,5-triaminobenzene (TAB) and 1,3,5-trichlorobenzene (TCB). MC-TCOP catalyst displayed excellent dibenzothiophene (DBT) conversion (99.6%) in the AODS reaction in 150 min, much higher than TT-COP (27.2%). In addition, MC-TCOP can be recycled for 9 times with lightly degression of catalytic performance. 2 Experimental particulars 2.1 Materials and reagents for catalyst synthesis Melamine (MA, 99%), cyanuric chloride (CNC, 99%), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, AR), benzoquinone (BQ, 99%), dibenzothiophene (DBT, 99%) and n-octane (C8H18, 96%) were acquired from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. 1,3,5-triaminobenzene (TAB, 95%), 1,3,5-trichlorobenzene (TCB, 99%) were provided by Shanghai Yi En Chemical Technology Co., LTD. Tertiary butanol (TBA, AR) and methyl alcohol (MeOH, 99.5%) were obtained from Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical Reagent Co., LTD. Oxygen gas (O2, 99%) were purchased from Yantai Feiyuan Special Gas Co., LTD. Deionized water was obtained from the FBZ (5-20) 01/02-UP model of ultrapure water machine. All the materials are used without additional purification steps. 2.2 The preparation process of MC-TCOP The preparation method of MC-TCOP was referred to the previous literature [32]. Scheme 1 illustrated the process of preparing the catalyst. That was, 5 mmol MA and CNC dissolved in DSMO respectively, stirring for 10 min until obtained two of transparent solutions. The solutions were transferred into a round bottomed flask, white suspension was gradually formed under continuously stirring, then the suspension was heated to 150 ℃ for 4 days, aging for 12 h under a standing state. Filtration, washed by DMSO, deionized water and MeOH, dried at 65 ℃ for 12 h in a vacuum drying oven. 2.3 The preparation process of TT-COP The preparation method for TT-COP is almost identical to that of MC-TCOP, with the exception being the utilization of raw materials (TAB, TCB) containing carbon-carbon bonds instead of carbon-nitrogen bonds. 2.4 Characterizations The surface structure and essential characteristic of the synthesized materials were analyzed by different characterizations. The data of solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was obtained from a BRUKER AVANCE NEO 400WB spectrometer, the number of scans was 1200, spectrometer frequency of 13C was 100.67 MHz with the temperature of 289.9 ℃. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out through the 300 model of ZEISS Gemini, the magnification was from 12x to 2, 000, 000x, distinguishability was 0.6 nm@15 kV or 1.0 nm@1 kV. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were analyzed using an infrared spectrometer (Nicolet-380), KBr was used as the background scanning, and the scans from 400 to 4000 cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained from a 6000 model of Shimadzu X-ray diffractometer (Cu-Ka irradiation, rated output power of 3 KW, λ = 0.15406 Å at 40 kV and 30 mA). The elemental and chemical state aspects of the catalyst was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, Al-Kα irradiation, 12 kV, 6 mA). The physical property of the catalyst was analyzed using ASAP-2460 physical adsorption apparatus, specific surface area, pore size and pore volume were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.5 Details of theoretical calculation The Gauss View 09 procedure was adopted to finish the Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations [33]. C, H and N as the basic elements of the material, and the dispersion correction of the density function was calculated by DFT-D3 method [34], the coordinates were completely optimized by the operational procedure, no imaginary frequency for the models. For the AODS reaction, the mono adsorption energy of catalyst to reactant (EDBT-ads), oxidant (EO2-ads) and the co-adsorption energy (ECo-ads) were calculated as Eqs. (1)–(3): (1) E O 2 − a d s = E O 2 − a d s − s t a t e − ( E C a t a l y s t + E O 2 ) (2) E D B T − a d s = E D B T − a d s − s t a t e − ( E C a t a l y s t + E D B T ) (3) E C o − a d s = E C o − a d s − s t a t e − ( E C a t a l y s t + E D B T + E O 2 ) EO2/DBT/Co-ads-state: total energy of the catalyst adsorbed oxidant, reactants, and both of them. EO2/DBT/Catalyst: basic energy of the catalyst, reactants and oxidant, respectively. 2.6 AODS experiment The simulated oil was used in the AODS reaction. A certain amount of DBT was dissolved in a volumetric flask contained n-octane, constant volume, and mixed, the final sulfur content of simulated oil was 500 parts per million (ppm). The AODS experiment consisted of adding 5 mL model oil and catalyst in a three-neck flask, transferring the flask to an oil bath, then feeding O2, stirring for some time under different temperatures. After reaction, the simulated oil was extracted by MeOH (the volume ratio of MeOH and simulated oil is 1:1). The residual content of DBT was tested through a microcoulomb comprehensive analyzer (JF-WK-2000). The calculation formula of desulfurization rate is as follows: η ( % ) = C 0 − C t C 0 × 100 % C0 (ppm): concentration of fresh simulated oil; Ct (ppm): concentration of residual simulated oil. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the synthesized material The basic characteristics of the catalyst included morphology and structure were analyzed by different characterization methods. PXRD pattern (Fig. S1) showed a featureless broad peak, and the diffraction peak at 2θ of 22.5° was aroused by the stacking of triazine linkage. No obvious crystal phases in MC-TCOP, indicating its amorphous structure, the previous reports also confirmed this conclusion [35–37]. SEM image (Fig. 1a ) showed the material possessed homogeneous spherical particle structure with uniformly distributed morphology. The architecture of MC-TCOP was analyzed by solid-state 13C NMR spectra (Fig. 1b). Strong signals around 166 and 47 ppm are attributed to the carbon of the triazine ring, signals around 55 ppm are resulted from C-N, another two signals around 150 and 155 ppm are belonged to the terminal unit, which originated from CNC [38–40], the results consisted the triazine structure in MC-TCOP. FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 1c) showed three peaks around 1539, 1357 and 800 cm−1 are attributed to triazine ring, and the intense peaks at 3425 cm−1 is assigned to the N-H stretching in amino groups and the -OH band from H2O molecules absorbed in air [41–43].The elemental and chemical state aspects of the MC-TCOP was analyzed by XPS spectrum (Fig. 1d), two peaks are observed in N 1s spectrum at the binding energy of 398.7 and 400.1 eV, which corresponding to the C=N-C and C-NH-C in MC-TCOP, respectively [44]. The above analysis consistently confirmed the successful synthesis of MC-TCOP with a triazine structure. The fundamental physical characteristics of MC-TCOP were further examined through the measurement of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and specific surface area of the catalyst. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution were shown in Fig. 2 . Specifically, Fig. 2a displayed a type IV isotherm with an H1-type hysteresis loop, indicating MC-TCOP's mesoporous nature, and the pore size distribution plot (Fig. 2b) also corroborated this perspective (the catalyst's mean pore diameter is distributed within the range of 3-5 nm). The physical parameters, including specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the catalyst, were presented in Table S1. These results of physical property analysis indicated the catalyst is a mesoporous material with a significantly large specific surface area. 3.2 AODS performance of the synthesized catalyst The AODS performance of the synthesized MC-TCOP was evaluated, and the blank experiment (without any oxidant) was also carried out (Fig. 3 ). When there were only 0.05 g MC-TCOP and 5mL model oil in the reaction system, the removal rate of DBT was 53% after 210 min, means only adsorption effect during the reaction process. However, the catalytic performance increased to 69.8% since O2 was introduced at the first 30 min, then 95.7% of DBT was oxidized in 210 min, indicated the oxidation effect dominated. In this reaction, both of adsorption and oxidation effect are indispensable to achieve a high conversion rate of DBT. Reaction conditions: T = 60 ℃, t = 210 min, MC-TCOP: 0.05 g, O2 flow: 70 mL/min. 3.3 Screening of technological conditions In this work, the technological conditions such as O2 flow, reaction temperature, reaction time and the ratio of catalyst to model oil were screened, in order to make sure the subsequent AODS experiments were carried out under an optimal condition (Fig. 4 ). The effect of O2 flow was first evaluated, Fig. 4a showed that the AODS performance of MC-TCOP was gradually increased, from 75.9% to 99.6% with the gas flow from 30 to 90 mL/min. However, the conversion rate of DBT unchanged even though the gas flow sequentially enhanced to 110 mL/min. The content of molecular oxygen was proportional to the gas flow, the DBT was more easily oxidized by the higher content of molecular oxygen. As a conclusion, 90 mL/min of the O2 flow was optimal for this reaction. Then the relationship between reaction temperature and AODS activity was also investigated, the result was shown in Fig. 4b. At the reaction temperature at 30 ℃, the conversion rate of DBT was 82.6%, then increased to 99.8% at 50 ℃ or 60 ℃. The higher reaction temperature accelerated the thermal movement rate of reactant and oxidant molecules, boosted interact of reactant and active sites of catalyst in the reaction system, which was conductive to convert DBT. Overall consideration, 50 ℃ was chose as the reaction temperature. The reaction time required in this study was also explored, the result was seen in Fig. 4c. At the first 30 min, the removal rate of DBT was only 76.5%, with the increasing of reaction time to 150 min, the AODS performance increased to 99.6%, 150 min was the optimal reaction time in this work. Catalyst has great influence in oxidizing DBT, the ratio of catalyst to model oil in this reaction was investigated and could be seen in Fig. 4d. 74.3% of DBT was removed at the ratio of catalyst to model oil of 0.002, undoubtedly, the removal rate of DBT increased fast as the ratio's increment, 99.6% of DBT was oxidized with the ratio increased to 0.008 (0.04 g MC-TCOP, 5 mL model oil). In short, 0.008 was the optimal ratio for removing of DBT. Table S2 showed the comparison result of desulfurization performance for different catalysts in the aerobic oxidation system. All these catalysts exhibited excellent AODS performance [15,22,23,45–50]. In particular, the ICDC (8) [23], rGO-425 [46], (NH4)5H6PV8Mo4O40 [48], and CAPP-DETA catalysts [50] were able to remove 100% of DBT in the AODS reaction. However, most of these catalysts required high temperature (≥ 100 ℃) and long time (≥ 240 min) to remove DBT, resulting in high energy consumption and processing cost. In contrast, MC-TCOP in this work is more promising in the successive research of AODS, for its capable of activating oxygen at lower temperature (50 ℃) and removing 99.6% of DBT in shorter time (150 min). 3.4 Control experiment and free radical quenching test After screening the optimal reaction conditions, the control experiment was proceeded to verification the catalytic active site (the carbon-nitrogen bond of triazine ring in the MC-TCOP). That was, prepared the catalyst (TT-COP) that without triazine structure. The two catalysts were used in the AODS reaction under the same reaction conditions to compare the conversion rate of DBT, the result was shown in Fig. 5a . The AODS performance of MC-TCOP was 99.6% while of TT-COP was 27.2%, which confirmed our viewpoint. After comparing the AODS performance of MC-TCOP and TT-COP, the types of active oxygen species were tested by the free radical quenching experiment (Fig. 5b). Two species of free radicals (•OH and •O2 −) were quenched by TBA and BQ, separately [51], the comparison group without any quencher was also did simultaneously. For MC-TCOP, the addition of TBA had barely effect on the AODS performance, indicated no •OH formed during the reaction, however, the conversion rate of DBT decreased from 99.6% to 60.6% when BQ was added to the reaction system, manifested the •O2 − was the main active oxygen. As to TT-COP, free radical quenching experiment (Fig. 5b) proved no reactive oxygen species formed in this reaction process, which also certified that the carbon-nitrogen bond in MC-TCOP was the principal catalytic active site. 3.5 Theoretical calculation The DFT calculations were carried out to further investigate the relationship among catalyst, reactant and oxidant (Fig. S2). The model of catalyst (Fig. S2a) was optimized by a DFT-D3 method, the subsequent calculations were based on the optimal model of catalyst. The single adsorption of catalyst for O2 or DBT and the co-adsorption were calculated, respectively, the results showed that the adsorption energy of the co-adsorption (Fig. S2d) was higher than any single adsorption energy (Fig. S2b, S2c). Besides, the single adsorption energy of the catalyst for O2 was much higher than for DBT, therefore, it was concluded that in the process of co-adsorption, O2 was first adsorbed, then was DBT. The theoretical calculation results were conducive to the deduction of the oxidation mechanism of the reaction. 3.6 Oxidation mechanism The oxidation mechanism (Fig. 6 ) was speculated according to the theoretical calculation and relevant experiments. During the reaction process, the carbon-nitrogen bond in the triazine structure of catalyst was the main catalytic active site, because in the structure of MC-TCOP, the charge difference generated by the different electronegativity between nitrogen and carbon (XN = 3.04 > XC = 2.55) [52,53], this kind of charge difference easily attracted O2 and activated it to form •O2 − [23], and the electron lost by the carbon atom was supplemented by the sulfur atom in the DBT, then •O2 − oxidized the DBT to DBTO, and further oxidized DBTO to DBTO2. 3.7 Reusability experiment The reusability of MC-TCOP was evaluated by the recycling experiment. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the simulated oil, washed by MeOH for several times, dried at 65 ℃ for 8 h, then the redried catalyst was used to the subsequent AODS reaction. There was no reduction of catalyst performance before the sixth recycle, and the conversion rate of DBT remained at 95.2% after recycling for 9 times (Fig. 7 ), the result indicated the MC-TCOP possessed a great retrievability. 3.8 Deactivation reason exploration of the catalyst During the cyclic test of AODS reaction, it was found that the removal rate of DBT was gradually decreased from the sixth cycle, and decreased to 95.2% at the ninth cycle, we ended the test and did several characterizations (XRD, SEM, BET) to the recovered catalyst, for figuring out the reason of catalyst activity reduction. There was no obvious difference in the XRD (Fig. S3) patterns between the fresh catalyst and recycled, no structure collapsed in MC-TCOP. However, the SEM images (Fig. S4) showed the catalyst existed serious aggregation phenomenon after reused for 9 times, the BET result of MC-TCOP R9 (Table S1) also confirmed the aggregation phenomenon (The specific surface area decreased from 438.4 to 107.9 m2 g−1). The aggregating catalyst covered part of active sites, and caused the decrease of AODS performance. The aggregation of catalyst maybe attributed to the gradual deterioration of electron mobility during the reaction, which leads to the aggregation of π-stacked layers [54]. 4 Conclusions A Triazine-based covalent organic polymer (MC-TCOP) was synthesized through a simple thermal condensation method. The material was used as a non-metal catalyst in the AODS reaction, which exhibited high conversion rate of DBT (99.6%) under mild conditi ons (50 ℃, 150 min, 90 mL/min of O2 flow, 0.04 g catalyst, 5 mL model oil). Possible reaction mechanism was proposed, the high removal rate of DBT was attributed to the charge difference between the nitrogen and carbon atoms of the carbon-nitrogen bonds in the structure of the MC-TCOP, that can easily attract O2 and activate it to formed into •O2 −. Moreover, the catalyst can be reused for 9 times without obvious decrease in activity, which exhibited high catalytic stability. MC-TCOP provided theoretical support for the designing and applying of subsequent metal free and environmentally friendly catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Aerobic oxidative desulfurization (AODS) has attracted significant attention due to the utilization of environmentally friendly and safe O2 as an oxidizing agent. However, it is still a great challenge to design metal-free catalysts that activate O2 effectively at low temperature. In this study, a triazine-based covalent organic polymer (MC-TCOP) was prepared through thermal condensation reaction, and the basic characteristics of the catalyst were analyzed by different characterization methods. The MC-TCOP was applied into the AODS reaction, and the catalytic performance reached to 99.6% under mild reaction conditions (T = 50 ℃, t = 150 min, gas flow = 90 mL/min, catalyst dosage = 0.04 g). Theoretical calculation showed O2 and dibenzothiophene (DBT) were co-adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst, and the reaction mechanism indicated the O2 was activated into •O2 − (by the charge difference between the nitrogen and carbon atoms), then the DBT was oxidized to corresponding sulphone. Moreover, reusability experiment confirmed the catalyst performance was still higher than 95% after 9 times of reusing. The MC-TCOP can be used as a metal-free and eco-friendly catalyst in AODS reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Triazine-based covalent organic polymer as a high aerobic oxidative desulfurization performance catalyst under mild reaction conditions
